title: Modular Training Methods at the Pacific Northwest Center for Cryo-EM Using Varied Learning Delivery Mechanisms
content: The process of training researchers in cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) practices and techniques is uniquely challenging due to the interdisciplinary nature of cryo-EM, as well as the broad range of scientific backgrounds, experience levels, and learning styles of the research community seeking to gain expertise in the field. At the Pacific Northwest Center for Cryo-EM (PNCC), we aim to train researchers in sample preparation, screening, single-particle (SPA) data collection, and data processing [1]. Our goal is that following completion of our programs, researchers can perform these workflows independently, either on PNCC instruments or at their local cryo-EM facilities. In order to achieve this goal, we employ strategic methods to effectively communicate ideas from biochemistry, physics, electron optics, and data analysis to researchers with varying degrees of familiarity and expertise in each of these disciplines.
